foundit66

2. Why should a candidate be for repealing DOMA? 
 
 Because the so-called "DOMA" or federal anti-marriage law passed in 1996 was a radical and cruel departure from 200+ years in which the federal government honored the marriages of Americans without discrimination. So-called DOMA creates two classes of marriage, first-class marriages for those the federal government likes, which receive more than 1000 legal protections and incidents, and second-class marriages, for those the government doesn't like, which get no access to this important safety-net that matters to couples, kids, and those interacting with them. In the United States, we don't have second-class citizens, and we shouldn't have second-class marriages, either. Government has no business putting obstacles in the path of Americans seeking to care for one another -- gay or non-gay. 
 
 3. What is Section Three of DOMA, which Senator Clinton wants to repeal, and what would remain if that section is taken out? 
 
 Senator Clinton, like all the other Democrats running for president, favors repeal of the worst provision of the federal anti-marriage law, the part that says that the federal government will not honor the lawful marriage of a taxpaying same-sex couple, thereby withholding from the 1138+ federal protections and responsibilities that marriage triggers. These include your family's access to your Social Security, fair treatment for your family under immigration law, fair treatment under tax laws, access to veteran's coverage, etc. What Senator Clinton has not yet addressed is the other part of so-called DOMA, which says that states can dishonor and destabilize marriages of people from other states. People should not have to worry whether their marriage will be honored and their family protected depending on where they are parking that day. 
 
 4. Are the candidates being politically wise in being for civil unions and not for marriage equality and should we support them in that political strategy? 
 
 No, and no, as discussed in my Huffington Post pieces above. Civil union, let alone the freedom to marry, doesn't just happen. Support for increments along the way comes through the engine of fighting for the freedom to marry, and the powerful, resonant, humanizing, shared vocabulary of marriage. It's not as if the candidates or society are generously offering civil union or partnership, etc., and we are somehow unreasonably asking for more; rather, it's our engagement -- asking for, fighting for, making the case for -- the full that has moved them on the partial. Marriage is the tug, and when gay people undercut that tug, it doesn't help our cause, or the candidates either. Those who are giving early support to particular candidates may have good reasons for doing so, but when we too quickly say "it's okay" for them not to support full equality (and even fudge what full equality is), it's not helpful. You can't get people to care if you begin by saying "I don't care," as in "I don't care what we call it," etc. And if we drop down, if we fail to do the heavy lifting (particularly at this very early stage of an unusually long presidential cycle), we do the candidates, our cause, couples, kids, and the country the disservice of not creating the space in which America (and its politicians) can rise to fairness.
 http://www.davidmixner.com/2007/08/evan-wolfson-ma.html#more

post_info.post_title: Marriage Equality and the Presidential Election

foundit66

Some great points, especially the part in red.
 It's one thing I think those that want us to just be quiet (in one form or another), and say they support gays don't get about the situation.
 Quiet got gays nowhere for centuries. People don't get equality by being quiet. Not blacks, women, or gays.
 
 It's only when people point out the discrimination and expose it for scrutiny that change happens.
JSDKoeln

Some great points, especially the part in red.
 It's one thing I think those that want us to just be quiet (in one form or another), and say they support gays don't get about the situation.
 Quiet got gays nowhere for centuries. People don't get equality by being quiet. Not blacks, women, or gays.
 
 It's only when people point out the discrimination and expose it for scrutiny that change happens.

 
 Where I am 100% for gay-marriage, I'm not sure it's possible in the curent socio-fundamentalist climate in the USA. Sure, if we only had to deal with the major metropolises and the liberal sectors of the US, marriage would pass in a heartbeat. But, alas, there is the heartland to contend with.
 
 Homosexuals have made great strides in their acceptance, visibility and rights over the last 40-50 years. I mean, if you think of where we are coming from in such a short amount of time, I think we're doing great--especially having the devastation of the whole AIDS crisis to contend with. That being said, we have to be careful of the other side. Where, as I stated, we're in the right to want marriage; however, I think the incremental approach for the next 20 years is the only way gays will eventually get to use the term "marriage." If we force so many people (registered voters) into something where they feel the least bit threatened, there will be a backlash. In a perfect world, reasonable people should see this and say... "hey, this minority is not being allowed to pursue their happiness. why do I have more rights than them?" But the US is far from perfect.... especially with all the money coming against us from the fundamentalist reich. 
 
 The reality is that civil-unions with FULL and EQUAL rights to that of a marriage would be acceptable, for now.... and is something I think is achievable, only by keeping the forbidden "M" word out of it. Once that is done (and look at Great Brittian for an example), people will start not seeing it as a big deal.... will see the sky hasn't fallen... and will look at the two separate institutions as pure stupidity and eventually abolish it and combine.
 
 Germany has been rather conservative in it's post WWII time. They've taken the incremental approach here to gay marriage and it's been educating people over the years. My neighbors are very cool with us... very accepting (of course, this is cologne). Some of them actually came to our union ceremony. But the same-sex marriage rights were amended a few years ago and expanded. There are a few more to go before it's exactly the same as a marriage. 
 
 Since we are the minority, we have to be careful not to alienate the majority. Where in-you-face activism is necessary at the beginning of any civil-rights crusade; the time then comes to organize and be inclusive and aware of the rest of the populace. Organization, education and a good plan is what will get us to marriage. Screaming and demanding and in-you-face tactics will just make the other side dig their heals in deeper, at this point.
samiinh

 Here in New Hampshire, not known as a bastion of liberalism, Civil Unions passed the state legislature this year. I am now covered under my partner's state sponsored (he's a state worker) health insurance. We are grateful.
JSDKoeln

Here in New Hampshire, not known as a bastion of liberalism, Civil Unions passed the state legislature this year. I am now covered under my partner's state sponsored (he's a state worker) health insurance. We are grateful.

 
 Oh, I hear you. I am covered by my partner's insurance here as well. I would not have been able to get the insurance if we were not legally a union. It's amazing. And I am REALLY greatful for that!
davenport15

Here in New Hampshire, not known as a bastion of liberalism, Civil Unions passed the state legislature this year. I am now covered under my partner's state sponsored (he's a state worker) health insurance. We are grateful.

 
 And this is a terrific breakthrough. My partner and I are coveered by my company's health insurance, and the state of Connecticut honors our Civil Union. That being said, I still have to pay tax on my partner's health insurance as imputed income because the federal government refuses to acknowledge our union.
 
 So it has to be marriage. Full and without exception.
 
 Civil Unions are not enough when we are treated differently under the law.
samiinh

The reality is that civil-unions with FULL and EQUAL rights to that of a marriage would be acceptable, for now.... and is something I think is achievable, only by keeping the forbidden "M" word out of it. 

 I don't agree with this at all - that is like saying that we should have invented 'black and white' unions rather than allowing interracial marriage, and maybe put the kids of such unions is segregrated but equal schools, just to make sure that they don't have to mix with kids who matter. Separate is not equal, separate means one group doesn't matter as much as the other group - only EQUAL is EQUAL.
JSDKoeln

 Well, ok. I can see your point as well. However, I'm looking at the reality of the religious right and their influence. What is achieveable in the short term and long term? I think people need to be educated. Equal IS equal. You are absolutely right. And eventually, I pray there IS equality for gays. But given the current trend in the US, I doubt very much that it is going to happen. The Religious hate groups are well organized and well funded against us. We have to be smart and make a plan to get to the equal status we are entitled to. New Jersey is just another step towards that equality we want. But it's going to take more states.... one at a time. But IF gays can achieve more and more equal rights along the way, then great. I believe eventually gay marriage will happen in the US, but it's not going to be very soon.... maybe not in my lifetime. It will happen though.
samiinh
I believe we will see gay marriage, especially if a democrat is elected to the presidency in '08. If another republican gets in, it won't happen. They support bigotry and hate.
JSDKoeln

I believe we will see gay marriage, especially if a democrat is elected to the presidency in '08. If another republican gets in, it won't happen. They support bigotry and hate.

 
 I don't know Sam. Seems like most Dems are compromising so they can remain in office. I mean, DADT was such a fiasco... I'd rather the president have a less "in-you-face" plan to achieve equality on a longer path. Has to be blind to the religious reich. So many states have gone against gay marriage. We have to be careful and turn the tide. I personally think it will take time. But I truly hope you are right!
Matthew S

I believe we will see gay marriage, especially if a democrat is elected to the presidency in '08. If another republican gets in, it won't happen. They support bigotry and hate.

 
 It is not so much the president we must sweep all republicans from office. As long as their platform is anti gay they are a danger to us. We will never make strides toward equality as long as even one republican remains in office anywere in the country.
Phyllis

I believe we will see gay marriage, especially if a democrat is elected to the presidency in '08. If another republican gets in, it won't happen. They support bigotry and hate.

 
 I wonder what context you are speaking of here. Traditionally, marriage has been an institution wholly governed by the individual states. It is true there are benefits allotted by the federal government, but the institution of marriage is mostly a state institution.
 
 So for clarification, what do you mean when saying that you believe we will see gay marriage in the event a democrat is elected in 2008?
samiinh

I wonder what context you are speaking of here. Traditionally, marriage has been an institution wholly governed by the individual states. It is true there are benefits allotted by the federal government, but the institution of marriage is mostly a state institution.
 
 So for clarification, what do you mean when saying that you believe we will see gay marriage in the event a democrat is elected in 2008?

 
 What I mean, is that DOMA will be over ridden and gay people will be included in the 1400 benefits of marriage granted by the federal government. Whether the word "marriage" will be part of it is anybody's guess.
Phyllis

What I mean, is that DOMA will be over ridden and gay people will be included in the 1400 benefits of marriage granted by the federal government. Whether the word "marriage" will be part of it is anybody's guess.

 
 You think this will happen just because a Democrat is President? How do you suppose it will happen?
lesz

You think this will happen just because a Democrat is President? How do you suppose it will happen?

 
 Why would you suppose it won't? It's hardly likely to happen if Republicans control government.
Phyllis

Why would you suppose it won't? It's hardly likely to happen if Republicans control government.

 
 It's hardly likely it will happen at all. That's the point I have made in the past. This is mostly because a President simply can't reverse a law. Reversing DOMA would have to be initiated by Congress. That is not likely to happen no matter who is the President.
lesz

It's hardly likely it will happen at all. That's the point I have made in the past. This is mostly because a President simply can't reverse a law. Reversing DOMA would have to be initiated by Congress. That is not likely to happen no matter who is the President.

 
 Well, the abolition of slavery wasn't considered likely to happen, neither was the granting of women's suffrage. Perhaps the latter was a mistake. Still, reform does happen, however much some people oppose it.
lesz

Still, obviously the election of a Democratic president won't assure passage of equal rights for gay people. However, the election of a Republican will ensure the blockage of equal rights. The GOP builds its platform on hatred of gay Americans.
samiinh

The current president makes law with executive orders. How could Bush by himself pull the US out of treaties made by other presidents and congresses? He did. 
 
 A new president could rescind DOMA with an executive order. Kings can do anything. Dictators too.
Phyllis

The current president makes law with executive orders. How could Bush by himself pull the US out of treaties made by other presidents and congresses? He did.

 
 Link please. 
 
 
A new president could rescind DOMA with an executive order. Kings can do anything. Dictators too.

 
 Wow. You think that the President can simply void a law for any reason that he would want to? Just like that?
 
 And you would actually support this type of illegal action? That's quite troubling. It is interesting that you want to change the law to say a certain thing so that everyone would have to follow it when you are willing to ignore the law in order to change it in the first place.
 
 I don't support lawlessness, and I can't understand why so many people in this forum do.

Phyllis

 Of course I haven't denied that the Republican candidates oppose gay marriage. I have, however, denied that such opposition is mostly rooted in bigotry.
 
 I have also questioned the sincerity of several democratic presidential candidates on account of their new-found outrage at DOMA. My point is that the President has no role to play in the revision of DOMA except to sign or not sign a bill that would come to him. Such a revision would have to be initiated by Congress. And that, as I have previously said, is not at all likely to happen.
lesz

Of course I haven't denied that the Republican candidates oppose gay marriage. I have, however, denied that such opposition is mostly rooted in bigotry.

 
 I have no evidence for it being rooted in anything else as far as the GOP is concerned. It isn't rooted in law or ethical principle.
 
 
I have also questioned the sincerity of several democratic presidential candidates on account of their new-found outrage at DOMA. My point is that the President has no role to play in the revision of DOMA except to sign or not sign a bill that would come to him. Such a revision would have to be initiated by Congress. And that, as I have previously said, is not at all likely to happen.

 
 Questioning the sincerity of presidential candidates is not exactly novel. And as you well know, presidents through patronage and political influence do have a strong role to play in what legislation comes before and gets passed by Congress. Of course legislation for gay equality isn't going to automatically follow a Democratic presidential victory, but in the current political climate, it could never follow a GOP victory.
jyoshu

It's interesting Phyllis doesn't deny that the GOP builds its platform against equal rights for gays.

 
 That's right--the only difference here between Phyllis and you isn't regarding the GOP, but rather that she isn't so naive to think that the Democrats are your automatic ticket to equality, as you obviously think. It's ridiculous to, every time someone dares question the Democrats, basically respond "but the GOP is worse!", as if that does anything whatsoever to address the intentions of Democrats and whether they would truly lead you to equality.
Phyllis

I have no evidence for it being rooted in anything else as far as the GOP is concerned. It isn't rooted in law or ethical principle.

 
 Lack of evidence for it being rooted in something other than bigotry is not evidence that it must therefore be rooted in bigotry. I'm not going to rehash a discussion that has already been had. If you want my view on the issue of bigotry as it relates to the issue of gay marriage, you can read this thread.
 
 
 
And as you well know, presidents through patronage and political influence do have a strong role to play in what legislation comes before and gets passed by Congress.

 
 I do not know this well. Congress is its own machine. It ultimately determines what legislation it wishes to enact.
 
 
Of course legislation for gay equality isn't going to automatically follow a Democratic presidential victory, but in the current political climate, it could never follow a GOP victory.

 
 In the current political climate, gay marriage cannot follow except through judicial fiat. It matters not who is president, or what party they are a member of. But that is not the point. The point is that no one should be singing the praises of Senators Obama or Clinton for their new-found stance on DOMA because it is obviously not rooted in principle, and no one should go around suggesting that when a democratic President is elected gay marriage will, in fact, follow. It will not, in fact, follow, and it is highly unlikely that it will.

It will not, in fact, follow, and it is highly unlikely that it will.

He was crucified by the right, compromised on a bad policy and the anti-clinton seed was planted that eventually resulted in a superfluous impeachment. I don't think the next dem candidate will make it a priority. They just want the gay vote because they don't want another Florida to happen. But if I do think if a Republican gets in, other than Guiliani, gay rights could be set back. I wish there was a strong 3rd party in the states. It is sorely needed. These two parties are just too polarized. Wasn't it the Republican party that was historically socially liberal and fiscally conservative? Whatever happened?

I too wish Republicans would return to this. And with the influence of the Religious Right waning (though ever so slowly), maybe it will happen one of these days.
